## About

This page documents the lab's work on the question of what factors contribute to the rise in diagnoses of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).

## Background

On October 29, 2025, U.S. Secretary of Health and Human Services (HHS) Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. said that there is not "sufficient" evidence to link use of Tylenol ([acetaminophen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paracetamol)) during pregnancy to autism [@Ramaswamy2025-ro].

In April, the Centers for Disease Control released a report [@Shaw2025-hr] from the Autism and Developmental Disabilities Monitoring (ADDM) Network [@CDC2025-ub].

Here is a figure to capture some of the associations:

```{mermaid}
flowchart TD
  B(sex) ---> A[ASD_dx]
  C(med household income) ---> A
  D(race) ---> A
  E(location) ---> A
  F(age_2022) ---> A
  A --- G[intellectual disability]
  D ---> G
  E ---> G
  F ---> G
  H(age_dx) ---> A
  E ---> I(use of ASD test)
  I ---> A
  J{health literacy} ---> A
```

### Autism diagnosis (dx) measures

@Shaw2025-hr assigned an autism diagnosis to children who met one of the following criteria:

>1) an ASD diagnostic statement in a comprehensive developmental evaluation, 2) autism special education eligibility, or 3) an ASD ICD-9 code in the 299 range or ICD-10 code of F84.0, F84.3, F84.5, F84.8, or F84.9. Children aged 4 years were classified as having suspected ASD if they did not meet the criteria for ASD but had an evaluator’s suspicion of ASD documented in a comprehensive developmental evaluation. 

- Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS), @ADOS-ed
- Autism Spectrum Rating Scales (ASRS), @NaglieriUnknown-dy
- Childhood Autism Rating Scale (CARS), @CARS-xe
- Gilliam Autism Rating Scale (GARS), @GilliamUnknown-ik
- Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS), @SRS-uj
- Autism Diagnostic Interview-Revised (ADI-R), @ADI-rm

::: {.callout-note}
All of the tests are available only to administrators who pay for the testing materials.
:::

Here is a paper that compares the ADOS to the CARS: @Park2018-wq.

[Autism Speaks](https://www.autismspeaks.org/) promotes this parent-completed survey: @M-CHAT2015-ke.

## Data exploration

The following documents an exploration of the data reported in tables in @Shaw2025-hr.

```{r}
#| label: setup
suppressPackageStartupMessages(library(ggplot2))
```

Download the data from the Google sheet stored here:

Table 1: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13XMwkWLzoEZ-laHWRNo2OfK6Te2wctjnXpBhKtMaMkA/edit?gid=0#gid=0

### Table 01

```{r}
#| label: import-data-table-01
#| message: false
#| eval: false
if (!dir.exists(params$csv_dir)) {
  message("Creating missing `include/csv/`.")
  dir.create(params$csv_dir)
}

options(gargle_oauth_email = Sys.getenv("GMAIL_SURVEY"))

table_01 <- googlesheets4::read_sheet("https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13XMwkWLzoEZ-laHWRNo2OfK6Te2wctjnXpBhKtMaMkA", sheet = "table-01")

readr::write_csv(table_01, file = "include/csv/wilson-2025-table-01.csv")

head(table_01)
```

```{r}
#| label: reimport-data-csv

table_01 <- readr::read_csv(file = "include/csv/wilson-2025-table-01.csv", show_col_types = FALSE)
```

Clean Table 01 names.

```{r}
#| label: clean-table-01

# Rename variables
table_01_clean <- table_01 |>
  dplyr::rename(
    area_desc = "Surveillance area description",
    sources = "Types of data sources used*",
    pop_pct_coverage = "% population coverage of education data sources†",
    cases_pct_avail = "% of cases with records available for abstraction at ≥1 source§",
    pop_total = "Total population",
    n_ASD = "No. with ASD",
    prev_ASD = "ASD prevalence (95% CI)¶"
  )
```

Parse the `prev_ASD` variable.

```{r}
n_sites <- length(table_01_clean$area_desc)
prev_numbers <- table_01_clean$prev_ASD |> 
  stringr::str_extract_all(pattern = "[0-9]+.[0-9]{1}") |>
  unlist() |> 
  array(dim = c(n_sites,3))

prev <- prev_numbers[,1] |> as.numeric()
CI_lo <- prev_numbers[,2] |> as.numeric()
CI_hi <- prev_numbers[,3] |> as.numeric()

table_01_clean$prev <- prev
table_01_clean$CI_lo <- CI_lo
table_01_clean$CI_hi <- CI_hi
```

Generate simple visualizations.

```{r}
#| label: fig-prevalence-histogram
table_01_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x=prev), bins = 5) +
  theme_classic()
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-pct_coverage-histogram
table_01_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x=pop_pct_coverage), bins = 5) +
  theme_classic()
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-pop_total-histogram
table_01_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x=pop_total), bins = 5) +
  theme_classic()
```

Generate simple visualizations for male/female data.

```{r}
#| label: fig-prev_male-histogram
table_02_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x=prev_male), bins = 5) +
  theme_classic()
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-prev_female-histogram
table_02_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x=prev_female), bins = 5) +
  theme_classic()
```

Make longer to enable better comparisons between male and female prevalence rates.

```{r}
#| label: create-table_02_sex
table_02_sex <- table_02_clean |>
  dplyr::select(Site, prev_male, prev_female) |>
  tidyr::pivot_longer(cols = c("prev_male", "prev_female"),
                      names_to = "sex") |>
  dplyr::mutate(sex = stringr::str_remove(sex, "prev_")) |>
  dplyr::rename(prev = "value")
```

Plot data by sex.

```{r}
#| label: fig-table_02_clean_sex_histogram

table_02_sex |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = prev, fill = sex), bins = 6)
```

```{r}
#| label: fig-table_02_clean_sex_histogram_faceted

table_02_sex |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_histogram(aes(x = prev, fill = sex), bins = 5) +
  facet_grid(rows = vars(sex)) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.position = "bottom")
```

Scatterplot data by sex.

```{r}
#| label: fig-table_02_clean_sex_scatterplot
table_02_clean |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = prev_male, y = prev_female)) +
  geom_smooth(aes(x = prev_male, y = prev_female)) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.position = "bottom")
```

Add point labels.

```{r}
#| label: fig-table_02_clean_sex_scatterplot_labeled
table_02_clean |>
  dplyr::mutate(high_prev_male = prev_male > mean(prev_male)) |>
  dplyr::mutate(labels = ifelse(high_prev_male, Site, NA)) |>
  ggplot() +
  geom_point(aes(x = prev_male, y = prev_female)) +
  geom_smooth(aes(x = prev_male, y = prev_female)) +
  geom_text(aes(x = prev_male, y = prev_female, label = labels), 
            nudge_y = .5, nudge_x = 2) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.position = "bottom")
```
